channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: How ICE Spread Coronavirus At Home And Abroad
item.description: An investigation by The New York Times and The Marshall Project reveals how Immigration and Customs Enforcement became a spreader of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Emily Kassie and Barbara Marcolini

item.title: The Last Reporter in Town Had One Big Question for His Rich Boss
item.description: His newspaper has withered under a hedge fund. His industry was in turmoil even before a pandemic. But Evan Brandt won’t stop chronicling his town.
item.dc:creator: Dan Barry and Haruka Sakaguchi
item.media:credit: Haruka Sakaguchi for The New York Times

item.title: Like ‘a Bus Accident a Day’: Hospitals Strain Under New Flood of Covid-19 Patients
item.description: I.C.U. units are reaching capacity. Nurses are falling sick, contributing to shortages. The new coronavirus spikes are challenging hospitals across the United States.
item.dc:creator: Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura, Shawn Hubler, Hailey Fuchs and David Montgomery
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jackson Memorial, the flagship hospital of Jackson Health System in Miami, has only 28 I.C.U. beds, out of 234, available.

item.title: Daily Virus Death Toll Rises in Some States
item.description: In several states where the virus has surged in recent weeks, the death toll is edging up. That may end a long period in which the national toll has steadily declined.
item.dc:creator: Farah Stockman, Mitch Smith and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
item.media:description: In Rye, N.Y., family members last week mourned Conrad Coleman Jr., who died from the coronavirus.

item.title: Officers Shot Latino Man Five Times in the Back, Autopsy Says
item.description: Andres Guardado was killed in Southern California last month. His family said he was working as a security guard for an auto body shop the day he was shot.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Jennifer Guardado, right, grieved for her brother Andres Guardado at a protest near the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department over his killing.

item.title: Wall Street Journal Staff Members Push for Big Changes in News Coverage
item.description: A letter from a group of Journal reporters and editors calls for “more muscular reporting about race and social inequities,” as well as skepticism toward business and government leaders.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy and Ben Smith
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The News Corp. building in Midtown Manhattan is home to The Wall Street Journal.

item.title: As a Flag Comes Down, Looking for a ‘New Mississippi’
item.description: Much of Mississippi galvanized around the effort to remove the state flag. Residents now want to seize on the momentum created by the triumph.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas

item.title: Thinking of Traveling in the U.S.? These States Have Travel Restrictions
item.description: A third of states have strict measures in place for visitors, from mandatory testing to quarantine requirements.
item.dc:creator: Karen Schwartz
item.media:description: In New Jersey, a road sign advises out-of-state visitors to call and learn if they must self-quarantine.

item.title: ‘It Would Be Like Losing a Little Bit of Me’: TikTok Users Respond to Potential U.S. Ban
item.description: Gen Z and millennial users have found community on the app, particularly during the last few isolating months. And for some of them, it’s their livelihood.
item.dc:creator: Taylor Lorenz

item.title: Facebook Said to Consider Banning Political Ads
item.description: The social network has been under intense pressure for allowing misinformation and hate speech to spread on its site.
item.dc:creator: Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Jason Henry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, has repeatedly said he would not police politicians’ ads and that the company was not an arbiter of truth.

item.title: A Rescue Plan for the Planet? Watch Our Debate Here.
item.description: A virtual event with eight speakers and one question: Has Covid-19 created a blueprint for combating climate change?
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Herman Benson, Who Fought Union Corruption, Dies at 104
item.description: A machinist and Socialist from the Bronx, he pushed trade unions to be more democratic and to depose crooked labor leaders.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: Adrian Gomez, Who Cared for Migrant Youth, Is Dead at 52
item.description: He worked at a shelter in Texas and as a juvenile probation officer; he wanted, his daughter said, to make a difference. He died of complications of the novel coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Sam Roberts

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.description: Lessons from the pandemic. A car-free future. Elephants in crisis. New fiction. Ennio Morricone dies. A behind-the-scenes look at the New York City subway. And more.
item.dc:creator: Anna Schaverien

item.title: Trump Says He ‘Aced’ Cognitive Test, but White House Won’t Release Details
item.description: President Trump has repeatedly ridiculed Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s fitness to be president. Mr. Biden’s campaign has called it a smear that has backfired.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.category: Reed, Walter, National Military Medical Center
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump speaking to reporters on Friday before leaving the White House.

item.title: Trump Rally Postponed, Campaign Says, Citing Weather
item.description: The event was set to be held in Portsmouth, N.H., on Saturday. The campaign delayed it amid ongoing concerns about President Trump attracting only small crowds at his events.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:description: President Trump at a campaign rally in Tulsa last month.

item.title: Goya Foods Boycott Takes Off After Its President Praises Trump
item.description: “We’re all truly blessed at the same time to have a leader like President Trump,” Bob Unanue said on Thursday at the White House. Critics said they would no longer use his products.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Julian Castro, the Democratic former presidential candidate, was one of many critics who noted that Goya Foods had been a staple of Latino households for generations.

item.title: She’s an Authority on Earth’s Past. Now, Her Focus Is the Planet’s Future.
item.description: The climate scientist Maureen Raymo is leading the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory at Columbia. She has big plans for science, and diversity, too.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Melissa Bunni Elian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maureen Raymo, who took over as head of the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory this month, with a core sample she studied as a student.

item.title: Utah Governor Declares State of Emergency After Protests Over Police Shooting
item.description: Protests erupted after the district attorney in Salt Lake City said there would be no charges against the officers involved in the May shooting of Bernardo Palacios-Carbajal.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: Iversen, Neil (Salt Lake City, Utah, Police Officer)
Fortuna, Kevin (Salt Lake City, Utah, Police Officer)
item.media:description: Protesters and police officers near the district attorney’s office in Salt Lake City on Thursday.

item.title: Student Loan Relief Denied in Some Fraud Cases
item.description: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is denying huge batches of relief requests from students whose schools defrauded them. Even those who aren’t denied are getting very little — or sometimes nothing.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Jessica Pons for The New York Times
item.media:description: Albert Paul Cruz says his degree from ITT Technical Institute is worthless. The Education Department agrees the school ripped him off, but it won’t relieve him of any of his debt.

item.title: Beyond the Milky Way, a Galactic Wall
item.description: Astronomers have discovered a vast assemblage of galaxies hidden behind our own, in the “zone of avoidance.”
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: The starry core of our spiral Milky Way galaxy, in an infrared image from NASA Spitzer Space Telescope. Obscured behind it is the South Pole Wall, a curtain of thousands of galaxies across at least 700 million light-years.

item.title: KFC Birthday Party Costs $18,000 in Covid-19 Fines in Australia
item.description: “That’s a heck of a birthday party to recall,” said Chief Commissioner Shane Patton of the Victoria police. Officers were led to a house where they found people hiding in the backyard, garage and under beds.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:description: New lockdown restrictions were implemented in Melbourne, Australia, after a surge in coronavirus cases.

item.title: Sutter Health’s Request to Delay $575 Million Settlement Is Denied
item.description: The large California hospital system wanted to postpone an agreement reached in a state antitrust case, as coronavirus cases rise.
item.dc:creator: Reed Abelson
item.media:description: Facade of the Sutter Health Alta Bates Herrick Campus medical center, a major local hospital in Berkeley, California in 2018.

item.title: ‘This Is Not a Boring History of Nagging Spinsters’
item.description: Women’s suffrage is the story of a political revolution — with all sorts of parallels to today.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Bennett and Veronica Chambers

item.title: How the Supreme Court and Americans Diverged Over Religion at Work
item.description: Two decisions this week gave religious employers greater power to fire workers and limit birth control coverage. Polls suggest that on such issues of religious exemptions, most Americans disagree with the court.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court handed down two 7-2 decisions on Wednesday that gave victories to religious employers.

item.title: A New Surge in Virus Deaths
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: California, After Riding a Boom, Braces for Hard Times
item.description: Early hopes for a quick rebound from the pandemic have yielded to worries about its long-term impact on state finances and the governor’s ambitious agenda.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty
item.media:credit: G L Askew II for The New York Times
item.media:description: Businesses in California had hoped that the state’s early pandemic restrictions would lead to a quicker, stronger recovery. That hasn’t happened.

item.title: Riots Long Ago, Luxury Living Today
item.description: High-end development has transformed some Black neighborhoods decades after they were scarred by unrest. And not by coincidence.
item.dc:creator: Emily Badger and Quoctrung Bui
item.media:credit: Matthew Lewis/The Washington Post, via Getty Images
item.media:description: H Street NE in Washington during riots after the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in 1968.

item.title: An Unexpected Struggle for Trump: Defining an Elusive Biden
item.description: With only six weeks to the Republican National Convention, President Trump has yet to find a framework for attacking his opponent.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: A series of national polls has shown President Trump trailing former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., often by double digits.

item.title: What Happens When You’re Disabled but Nobody Can Tell
item.description: The author and clinical psychologist Andrew Solomon examines the disabilities that ramps and reserved parking spots don’t address.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Solomon

item.title: Why Trump’s White Grievance Message Strikes a Sour Note in the Suburbs
item.description: As the president casts himself as a bulwark against “angry mobs,” there are signs that he is alienating voters in bedroom communities who view him as a deeply flawed messenger on issues of race.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Swikar Patel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lake Norman in the suburban community of Cornelius, N.C.

item.title: Why Is a Tech Executive Installing Security Cameras Around San Francisco?
item.description: Chris Larsen knows that a crypto mogul spending his own money for a city’s camera surveillance system might sound creepy. He’s here to explain why it’s not.
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles

item.title: Homeland Security Turns to Defending Statues Amid Questions Over Priorities
item.description: The current leaders of the Department of Homeland Security have proved adept at following President Trump’s lead. Their latest target: guarding monuments and memorials.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: Department of Homeland Security agents guarding the North Carolina Monument on the Fourth of July in Gettysburg, Pa.

item.title: Meet the Heroes Fighting on the Front Lines Against Covid-19
item.description: Watch the doctors and nurses trying to save us from the coronavirus as they risk their own lives — and those of their families — in a new Times documentary on FX and Hulu.
item.category: New York University Langone Medical Center

item.title: How ICE Helped Spread the Coronavirus
item.description: The New York Times, in collaboration with The Marshall Project, investigated how Immigration and Customs Enforcement became a domestic and global spreader of the virus.
item.dc:creator: Barbara Marcolini, Emily Kassie, Dmitriy Khavin and Drew Jordan

item.title: Mail Carrier in West Virginia Pleads Guilty to Attempted Election Fraud
item.description: Five mail-in ballot requests were altered from Democrat to Republican, federal prosectors in West Virginia said.
item.dc:creator: Azi Paybarah
item.media:description: Election workers sorted vote-by-mail ballots for the Washington State presidential primary in March.

item.title: Congress Presses Military Leaders on Suspected Russian Bounties
item.description: Two House hearings grappled with a C.I.A. assessment that Russia offered payments to kill American troops in Afghanistan — and White House inaction on the months-old judgment.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Gen. Mark A. Milley, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of staff, and Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper, left, testified at a House Armed Services Committee hearing on Thursday.

item.title: How a Conservative Supreme Court and Trump's Appointees Declared Their Independence
item.description: The Supreme Court’s dismissal of President Trump’s claims of immunity was a reminder that institutional prerogatives still matter in Washington, even in a time of extreme partisanship.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Thursday, the Supreme Court categorically dismissed President Trump’s claim to “absolute immunity” against investigators seeking his tax returns.

item.title: Trump on Releasing His Tax Returns: From ‘Absolutely’ to ‘Political Prosecution’
item.description: The Supreme Court’s decision adds another twist in a yearslong debate over whether the president should release his tax returns.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Wednesday. He has promised to release his tax returns under varying conditions for nearly a decade.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: There are signs the death rate, which had stayed relatively low during the current surge, is starting to climb.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe

item.title: Trump Appointee Might Not Extend Visas for Foreign Journalists at V.O.A.
item.description: The action could be a blow to the news-gathering abilities of Voice of America, an independently operated media agency funded by the government.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for Global Media
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Voice of America studio in Washington, in 2018.

item.title: Judge in Michael Flynn Case Asks for Full Appeals Court Review
item.description: After a divided appeals court panel ordered him to drop the charge against the former national security adviser, a judge asked the full court to review the ruling.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s former national security adviser, twice pleaded guilty to lying to the F.B.I.

item.title: John Roberts, Trump Tormentor
item.description: The chief justice keeps ruling against the president. Legal scholars are debating his motivations.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Lerer

item.title: Robert Fuller’s Hanging Was a Suicide, Investigation Finds
item.description: The case was one of two hangings in California that drew scrutiny amid nationwide protests after the killing of George Floyd. Both have been ruled suicides.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio
item.media:description: Pallbearers carried Robert Fuller’s coffin after his funeral on June 30.
